official-title.#text: To establish a Road Usage Fee Pilot Program to study mileage-based fee systems, and for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

committee-name.#tail: , and in addition to the Committees on
, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

short-title.#text: Road Usage Fee Pilot Program Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds the following:
recommends a transition away from the fuel tax to a more stable funding source, noting that a mileage-based fee system is the consensus choice for policy leaders.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: National Surface Transportation Infrastructure Financing Commission
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Surface Transportation Infrastructure Financing Commission

text.#text: The 2009 report of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: recommends further study of the implementation of mileage-based fee systems at the State level and of their compatibility with a national revenue system, noting that in the long run, a mileage-based fee system seems the most likely and appropriate method to be implemented.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: National Surface Transportation and Revenue Study Commission
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Surface Transportation and Revenue Study Commission

text.#text: The 2008 report of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the revenue raised from the gas tax since its last increase in 1992 has lost over one-third of its purchasing power due to increasing fuel efficiency, changing transportation patterns, and inflation.

text.#text: According to the
By 2030, the corporate average fuel economy standards will have reduced Highway Trust Fund receipts by more than 20 percent.
The fuel tax revenue mechanism results in some industries paying more than their commensurate road use.
Since 1990, while gas tax revenues have consistently decreased, the number of vehicle miles traveled nationally has consistently increased.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: (in this Act referred to as the

term.#tail: ) shall establish a competitive grant program to be known as the Road Usage Fee Pilot Program (in this Act referred to as the
) to make grants to eligible entities to—

text.#text: The
conduct pilot studies of methods for recording and reporting the number of miles traveled by particular vehicles;
conduct pilot studies of payment, enforcement, and privacy protection methods for mileage-based fee systems; and
implement mileage-based fee systems in jurisdictions that have adopted a plan for such systems.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: an application at such time, in such form, and containing such information and assurances as the
may require.

text.#text: To be eligible for a grant under the Program, an eligible entity shall submit to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall select pilot studies that, in combination, explore means to address the following concerns:

text.#text: In awarding grants under the Program, the
Protection of personal privacy.
Ease of public compliance.
Level of public acceptance.
Geographic and income equity.
Integration with State and local transportation revenue mechanisms.
Administrative issues.
Cost.
Enforcement issues.
Potential for fraud or evasion.
Feasibility of implementation.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall give priority to pilot studies that—

text.#text: In awarding grants under the Program, the
serve as a model for broad implementation of a mileage-based fee system;
address concerns of rural and urban user equity;
involve multistate projects;
have a high volume of enrolled vehicles;
integrate with State and local revenue systems;
integrate with local demand management plans;
are likely to lead to implementation of mileage-based fee systems, dependent on the results of the program;
integrate with other intelligent transportation system technologies; and
test the proposed revenue collection system by collecting and distributing revenue.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall ensure that not less than 10 percent of funds available under the Program in a fiscal year are reserved for pilot studies carried out in conjunction with metropolitan planning organizations or regional transportation planning organizations.

text.#text: In awarding grants under the Program, the

header.#text: Required minimum funds for planning organizations

text.#text: An eligible entity that receives a grant under this Act shall provide funds, from non-Federal sources, in an amount equal to 20 percent of the amount of grant funds provided to the entity to carry out the activities supported by the grant.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , in consultation with the
, shall establish the following working groups:

text.#text: The
A technology and privacy working group that shall—
evaluate the technology platforms and standards used in the Program;
develop national technology standards and make recommendations to provide consistency in transportation data laws; and
balance the effectiveness of revenue systems with user privacy.

A transportation system and equity working group that shall evaluate the costs of collection and administration of methods studied in the Program and the success of such methods in achieving rural and urban user equity.
An environmental working group that shall evaluate the potential of the methods studied in the Program to manage demand and to reduce the emission of greenhouse gases.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall be comprised of at least 1 member with relevant subject-matter experience in the private sector and at least 1 member with relevant subject-matter experience in the public sector.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Road Usage Fee Pilot Program Act of 2013/s:4/ss:a

text.#text: Each of the working groups established under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall submit to
an interim report describing the progress of the Program, the progress of the working groups established under
, and any data or results from the Program.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Road Usage Fee Pilot Program Act of 2013/s:4/ss:a

text.#text: Not later than 2 years after the date of the first disbursement of funds under a grant under the Program, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall submit to

a final report containing data and results from the Program, an analysis of the feasibility of each method studied to be used as a mileage-based fee system, and the evaluations done by the working groups established under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Road Usage Fee Pilot Program Act of 2013/s:4/ss:a

text.#text: Not later than 4 years after the date of the first disbursement of funds under a grant under the Program, the
In this Act:

term.#tail: means one or more of the following:

text.#text: The term
A State government or political subdivision thereof.
A local government or political subdivision thereof.
A metropolitan planning organization.
A regional transportation planning organization.
A tribal organization.
